ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Helped me understand myself better.
I gained an understanding of mental disorders, learning how to recognize the sociocultural, biological, etc factors that influence their construction.
An array of abnormal psychological issues.
I learnt a lot about psychological disorders. Specifically, the risk factors, etiology  and statistics surrounding them.
A broad overview of clinical psychological disorders and etiology. Good insight into current clinical views about development and treatment of disorders.
Abnormal Psychology, mental disorders, course eliminated prejudices and educated about the truth about mental illness.
I was taught the DSM-5 for psychiatric disorders with some basic additional information about abnormal psychology.
I learned about a wide variety of mental illnesses in the DSM and their etiologies and treatments.

I learned a lot about the symptoms, etiologies, histories, and treatments of different mental illnesses. We learned how to apply these concepts to real-world examples, like movies, TV shows, books, and online articles.

I took this after a few more advanced psych classes that delve deeper into the stuff that is only covered briefly in this class, so honestly a lot of the material was stuff I already knew. However, I did learn some new things about other areas, and I feel like I have a broader knowledge of psychopathology, even if not deeper.
Different psychological diseases as well as methods of treatment.
I learned about a wide array of mental illnesses and the DSM criteria for them.

We covered a good amount of ground regarding different types of clinical diagnoses that can be found in the DSM. Learning about these helped me to realize what qualifies for a diagnosis and what does not.
Knowledge on abnormal psychological disorders and diagnosing criteria

Learned a lot about mental health and mental illnesses. Even though mental illness is a topic many of us likely have experience with/have some background knowing, I learned a lot of new things and the class cleared up some misconceptions as well.
Exploration of many topics in psychological field
Schizophrenia
I felt like it was actually a lot of interesting material; you basically just learn the DSM.
Symptoms, causes, and treatment for psychological illnesses and stigmas around them
This class provides you with good foundations on diagnostics and neurobiology of common mental health disorders.
Learned more about mental illnesses that has caused me to be more aware of my surroundings
Great class, learned a lot about various topics in abnormal psych.

I  barely learned anything this course barely scratches the surface of abnormal psych. You will learn the same amount in intro psych from the one or two abnormal lectures, except in this course you waste a whole semester on something you could learn in 2 days.
Etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of psychological disorders.
I learned about many different disorders
I learned about common psychological disorders (diagnoses, symptoms, treatments, etiological models, etc.)
The most you learn out of this is just the DSM criteria for many different disorders.
Learned what people with certain disorder go through and how some are treated.
learned a lot about different disorders and approaches to treatment as well as the different approaches to understanding them
Very few
I developed understanding and empathy for those with mental disorders and struggles. I also learned specifics about the different mental illnesses.
I gained a brief overview of various mental illnesses.
I learned a lot about what mental disorders truly are- and how prevalent they are in our society today.
This course covers a lot of mental disorders and provides a good background in diagnosing and treating people with mental illnesses.
All about mental disorders.

I learned so much about the psychological disorders that affect thousands of people around the world in different ways. These disorders are highly misunderstood by society and create harmful stigmas that hurt those who are diagnosed.

Learned about the research methods in psychology and about many different mental disorders that exist in the DSM-5 today. How these diseases are characterized, diagnosed, treated, their etiology, etc.

I learned about a multitude of different disorders, how they are characterized in the DSM-5, and how the world views and treats people with disorders, often stigmatizing the disorders and the people themselves.
I learnt a ton about mental disorders, mood disorders, suicide, personality disorders etc.  Helped me think more critically about psychiatric  and psychological disorders and the stigma they carry.

The course draws heavily from the DSM in its teaching, so I learned about the symptoms of specific mental disorders and how those symptoms are manifested in real life. This course does a good job of dispelling most misconceptions people have about mental disorders and how those disorders are expressed, which I thought was the more interesting part of this class.
A new perspective on many psychological disorders.
Learned about basics to psychology & details about certain mental illnesses.
This was an interesting class in which I learned a lot of new material using background knowledge of psych.
I learned a lot about mental illness and its prevalence in the world.
I learned about the prevalence, symptoms, and treatments of various mental disorders.
This course taught you the diagnostic criteria, possible causes behind, and treatments derived from these causes, for a wide range of mental disorders.

I was able to learn about different mental illnesses and the stigma and symptoms associated with each. It was a good experience for me to learn the ways in which you can distinguish between different conditions and how impairing they can be in daily life.
A lot about different abnormalities.

I learned a lot about mental disorders and mental illness and also the importance of mental health. I also learned about mental health treatment, the stigmatization of mental disorders and their role in society.
How to better identify and understand psychological conditions.
Different disorders and the background and causes of them
Learned some great introductory abnormal psych knowledge
I felt like I learned a lot about abnormal psychology. The movie/book paper was quite a waste and exams are worth a lot
I learned so much about the various mental disorders people struggle with.
I learned a lot about abnormal psychology and how important it is in everyday life
Honestly nothing

So cool course. you learn so much about things you didnt know before, and probably wouldnt have without taking the course. highly recommend. you understand people around you and yourself better after this course.
I learned about a wide array of different mental disorders.

I learned the main characteristics of different mental disorders from multiple research perspectives, the impact that clinical disorders has in people lives, and in general, how to be a better person and friend with people with mental disorders.
Deeper understanding of the importance of mental health and the burdens it places on our health care system
I learned a lot about many different psychological disorders and their causes and treatments. There was also social implications that we studied.
Learned about symptoms and etiology of mental disorders (schizophrenia, eating disorders, depression, ect) and how to diagnose them
How to identify and treat abnormal phyc
Exploration of a lot of different topics in abnormal psych, including anorexia, bipolar disorders, substance abuse disorders, phobias
Introduction to mental disorders, etiology, symptoms, and treatment.
I learned about various mechanism and disorder of mental health. I learned to have empathy for mental disorders and their realities.
A better perspective on mental health crises.
learned how to read the DSM-5
Learned about many mental disorders, what the models of etiology look like, and various forms of treatment and study of these disorders.
I learned about the diagnostic criteria and etiological theories for a number of mental disorders
I learned a lot about disorders we hear about often, but that are considered abnormal. I could identify and distinguish between certain disorders at this point.
This course is a good overview of different categories of disorders, their etiological roots, and treatment approaches.

I learned a lot about carefully evaluating mental illnesses and disorders. This is a course that the average student can take; it's very useful. For that reason I think every student in the Psych major should take this course as well. This course is really important for understanding the nuances in clinical psychology.
Mostly, I learned about the DSM 5; how it came to be, how each disorder within it was decided upon, how these diagnosis's create and perpetuate stigma or else exclude people who need care.
This class was helped in knowing some of the symptoms of some mental disorder and illnesses. It was also very informative, the articles, the Tedtalks, it was interesting and needed.
Knowledge of psychological disorder and reading analysis
You learn about the different psychological disorders.
Very interesting, great class!

I learnt to think about mental illness in a completely different way. Taking a clinical perspective on such a variety of mental illnesses was really eye-opening, and I think that this should be a class that all students here should take.

Learned so much! On a high level, I learned about people and how to be more understanding of people's unique circumstances and personalities. On a more detailed level, I learned about psychological disorders, their etiologies and treatments.

De-stigmatize mental illnesses and the prevalence of them within society just comes to show how much better we as a collective must work towards helping provide access and better treatments for mental illnesses.
I learnt about wide range of mental disorders; causes, symptoms, prevalence and treatment.
I learned more about psychology.
super brief overview of all the disorders but quite informative

I gained so much knowledge on the intricacy of mental disorders and their course of development. Being able to study the rigor that goes into diagnosis and treatment has aided my larger understanding of how advanced psychology has become and the gravity of the symptoms of these disorders.
I learned a lot about how we develop and what makes others normal compared to others.
I developed a thorough understanding of the different psychological disorders.
I gained knowledge of various mental disorders and etiologies of the disorders.
I learned a lot about the human mind and psych disorders.

I developed a solid understanding of many types of mental disorders and methods of diagnosis. The course also deepened my understanding of and general sensitivity toward those diagnosed with mental disorders.

I learned A LOT in this class. There was so much about mental illness that I didn't actually know, but didn't know I didn't know. This lecture provided an incredible amount of information about mental illness and it further enhanced my passion for the mind and the way it works. I hope I retain a good amount of this information because it was so interesting and will probably be very useful in the path I take in the future.
This course covers some material from Intro Psych, and then offers comprehensive views on the definitions, symptoms, etiology, prevalence, and treatments of various psychological disorders.
I learned how to see human behavior through various lenses.

I received a great overview of abnormal psychology and all the disorders and issues that fall under that subset of psychology. In addition to gaining a thorough understanding of the latest edition of the DSM, I also developed great insight into what are the pros and cons of diagnosing people and what is controversial about certain disorders and treatments.

I developed knowledge about the specifics of how to diagnose disorders, the criteria that have to be met and the differentiation between different categories of disorders as consistent with the DSM-V.
I learned about the DSM and different "abnormal" psychology disorders including their risk factors, symptoms, and treatment methods.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor is knowledgeable and available, material is interesting.
Weaknesses: lectures and slides are not very engaging, and neither are reading responses.

The lectures are very dry and youre just expected to copy down the slides to your notes, which doesnt seem like the most effective way to learn the material. The midterms ask questions that feel unreasonably specific, and theres no application of concepts - its merely regurgitating facts.

Strengths: I enjoyed the weekly readings for our response papers. They were interesting and helped me understand the relevance of the course content in the real world.

Weaknesses: I thought the review paper could be restructured. I think the page requirements for each given section should be more flexible, to account for the fact that any given book or movie will provide different information for analysis.

Strengths: Topics are super interesting, material is available readily
weaknesses: Prof Joormann can be hard to understand sometimes- takes a long time to get through the day's lecture. Tests are worth way too much of final grade
None
could provide recorded lectures to review or for when a student misses a day of class.

Teaching: not engaging, dry facts, though interesting contents.
- class strongly related to contents in the textbook, which facilitated learning, but also made the class less engaging since the exact same concepts were covered - doubling up on topics...
Very fair exams, testing the basic knowledge, not too much unnecessary detail. well organized syllabus.
The content is interesting but I think the lecture could be a little more engaging.

The course has a wide scope of topics (I felt that everything in the DSM and considered a mental illness was touched on), but the depth of study is extremely shallow. I did not feel I learned significantly more than I would have taking intro psyc.
Interesting information but boring lecture.

Strengths: really interesting and applicable course content. Prof. Joormann did a great job in conveying a lot of information each class in an engaging way. Very reasonable course expectations--exams were fair. I am certain that I will use the knowledge gained in this class in many different aspects of my life and career.

Weaknesses: I would rather have read more scientific articles for the reading responses. I enjoyed the book I read for the paper, but I wished that I could have written a more open-ended paper about my thoughts and reactions to the text as opposed to following the strict format dictated by the assignment.

Strengths: Interesting material, fair coursework load, good preparation for exams, interesting readings for discussion questions, PollEv questions to help go over the material
Weaknesses: Despite the fascinating material, some lectures were not engaging. I would also recommend changing the course name from "Abnormal" psychology. I also wish there had been more warnings in advance about triggering material that would be discussed during lecture.
Interesting subject matter, lecture not terribly interesting.

I enjoyed this course and the content was very interesting. Prof. Joormann is kind and engaging. The only improvement could be not starting new lecture topics at the end of class, as it often became hard to keep track of notes and topics when they didn't align consistently with the class days.
Grades are too heavily weighted toward the exams, should be more evenly distributed between book/movie paper and assignments (and exams).

It is interesting material, but it could be delivered in a more engaging manner. We just went through powerpoint slides with bullet points, and a lot of people lost interest quickly. The amount of people there for lecture was about half or even a third of the amount of people who showed up for the exams.

strengths - low work load
weakness - very poorly run review sessions
It's a large lecture, so not a lot of student engagement. Not to say that the lectures aren't interesting - they are - but a huge lecture is still a huge lecture.
The lectures are packed with information, but I wished they weren't presented as factsheets that could be learned from the textbook but more thought-provoking arguments and narratives.
I would change the lectures to be a bit more exciting though the material was great and the professor had an immense wealth of knowledge
Interesting information
Lecture was not really helpful. I did well on the tests just by skimming the book and lecture slides.

strengths: interesting content, well taught, engaging, interesting reading material
weaknesses: boring at times

Pedagogically, I thought the course was very well designed. Exams were fair and helpful, and the lecture slides were a great mixture of raw information and expansive context. The reading responses and the papers we were responding to were very helpful for engaging with the material in the real world. The final paper, an analysis of mental illness experienced by a character in a book or movie, was an excellent way of integrating this material into our experience of the world around us. Additionally, on a public health level, I think the class serves an important role in giving students tools to identify mental health issues that people in our communities may be experiencing.
Good lectures, exams were fair and stuck to lecture material
Jutta is not an engaging lecturer and spends an hour and 15 minutes harping on the same simple point.

Strengths:
Weaknesses: lecture content could be more organized; they mostly restated the DSM most of the time, which made it hard to stay engaged.
I thought it was well taught.
The course is good overall. It's not too challenging at all. Certain topics are more interesting than others, so at times the class is interesting; other times it is somewhat boring.
I think it could have been more connected somehow and also could have been more engaging. It tended to just be like a summary of the DSM for many different disorders.
Class should relate more to book.
great class! fair, interesting, not stressful
This class was boring

The lecture style was very dry and uninteresting, even though the information should have been interesting. With Professor Joormann, such an expert in the field, I would have found the information so much more if she had included anecdotes from her own experience with the information. Most of the time it felt that the information was a regurgitation of the DSM, rather than a lively presentation of exciting information.

The strengths of this course are that the TAs and professor are very responsive to questions and meeting to discuss topics outside of class. The weaknesses are that the lectures were often not very engaging. However, the Poll Everywhere questions, videos, and guest lecturers helped with this. The professor often read off of the slides and sometimes was a little hard to follow. Additionally, the material taught on the various mental illnesses was very surface level. If one had taken AP Psychology in high school or Intro to Psychology here at Yale, this class would probably be very repetitive and boring. The exams were very straightforward (multiple choice and short answer questions) and non-cumulative which was very nice given the amount of illnesses and etiological paradigms that were covered.

Weaknesses are the fact that each lecture is formatted in the same way: a disorder, symptoms, potential causes, and treatments. This format gets dry and makes classes feel long and tough to sit through. The material itself is interesting, but the lectures are structured in a less interesting way.

Strengths: Prof Joormann is great, the course material is interesting, and the class is not too difficult.
Weaknesses: The course is a brief overview of a lot of topics, so we didn't go too in detail with a lot of the disorders.
great course

I love how the course was structured. Everything seemed very organized as we learned about the different disorders. It was very easy to follow the lecture. However, I wish we had more assignments that could help our grade out instead of relying on 2 tests.

Strengths are that it was a very interesting course and the teaching staff was very helpful with office hours and review sessions. The weekly reading response was also helpful in helping students think about the outside material they read for the class. Overall great course, wouldn't change a thing!

The course content was very captivating, and the reading responses are actually very informative and interesting to do. I would look forward to doing the reading responses every week, which would offer a new perspective on a certain disorder or how a person copes with the disorder in their daily life.

strengths: the class is super easy 
weakness: you won't get much out of the class
The lecture is interesting, but only if you attend. The TAs are not very visible and keep canceling their office hours.

Strengths: the overviews of each disorder are very detailed and provide a lot of important information about them. The course also uses a lot of case studies and videos which helps with the general understanding of the disorders. Also, the course made a point of never being judgmental about any of the disorders which was good. Respectful language and attitudes were used throughout.
Weaknesses: I (along with many other students) found it frustrating when Professor Joormann would start a new topic/new set of lecture slides when there were 10 minutes left of class. I would recommend either better pacing or simply ending class early.
Exam's are worth too much of overall grade. Difficult to show true comprehension of material by 2 exams. Textbook is dull. Joormann's lectures are quite interesting albeit lengthy.
Strengths are that it is interesting and expectations are clear and straight-forward. A weakness is sometimes the 75 minute lectures can feel a little long.
The lectures werent super engaging but the material was interesting. The grading in the class seemed very fair.
I think the powerpoint slides could be a little bit more structured.

The strengths of this course are the reading responses and the material we get for those. The TedTalks and articles are very interesting to read. Another strength of this course is the information learned in it. A weakness is the way the information was presented in lecture.

The main strength of this course is that it teaches you about mental illness have affected nearly everyone either directly or indirectly. I also really enjoyed the videos that we watched in class because it helped make the textbook material more real and more memorable. I also really benefitted from having the Poll.Ev check in questions because it helped me check my knowledge incrementally, which is so helpful when it finally comes time to review for the larger midterm and final. It helped you realize along the way what you knew well and what you didn't.
The course could be improved by updated lecture slides, and clearer lecture structure.

it could have been improved by more discussion of the lecture rather than simply reading off of the powerpoint notes. The course is less engaging and it prevents people from wanting to go to class when the lecture slides can just be read. That being said the information covered in the class was interesting and I personally enjoyed going and listening.
The midterm was specific and did not show learning levels.
Interesting course content.
There was so much material that it could be difficult to follow sometimes, and sometimes it was hard to engage with the material since it was only presented one way.

Strengths- interesting subject matter, manageable workload 

Weaknesses- lectures could be boring
Taught straight off the lecture slides, more engagement

Jutta and her slides are the biggest strength of this course. She just makes it very easy to understand, and she's a funny lecturer. Her assignments were engaging and helped us understand disorders better.
Good class. Interesting lecture and good professor
Seriously improved... how are exams worth 80% literally does not make sense
I think throwing something else in there besides the two major tests worth 80% of your grade would be appropriate.

The textbook and the professor's lectures covered the same material. I would have appreciated if the latter was more engaging. The professor also did not follow the class according to the syllabus and it was confusing at times on what material should be covered in a week.
The strengths of this course rely on the lectures. Prof. Joorman is super nice and makes the lecture very engaging and human.
While the material in this course is interesting, the lectures are very boring. Dr. Joormann is not very engaging and does a lot of repeating exactly what is on the slides.
It was straightforward and interesting.

Lecture were not super boring. Professor Joorman seems really passionate and is a pretty good lecturer and brings in her previous experiences as a psychiatrist to tie into the lecture. Weaknesses are that the lecture slides are kind of disorganized and don't explain as much (highly recommend going to lectures and taking notes)
Very solid survey of psychopathology, I would not change anything about this course.
It's not a lot of work and the lectures are really interesting! The tests are reasonable and the reading responses are interesting to do
some material/videos were obsolete, but overall great textbook and lecture selected material.
This course was over all conducted very well. it would be nice to have some sort of sample study questions before exams.

The class was very poorly organized, Professor Joorman's lecture's were confusing and not engaging, the reading responses were interesting but felt disconnected from the course, depending on your Tf, you got almost no feedback.

I thought Professor Joorman did a great job lecturing! The class was well-organized and the assignments were good.  I would say in the future maybe deviating from the textbook a bit more and covering more recent developments/anecdotal stories etc. would help connect the material together more.
more engaging lectures

I greatly enjoyed the content of the class, and the assessments were very reasonable. I did find the weekly responses quite disengaging, and I wonder if it would be better to require some more analytical assignment that occurred less often (for example, every 2-3 weeks).
It's a great lecture to take for students who don't have a lot of extra time. Very minimum requirements, and great content.

Strengths: readings for responses were interesting and always added to the lecture and textbook info
weaknesses: often ran out of time in lectures which sometimes meant missing out on information

strengths: very detailed, very nuanced, a good intro course
weaknesses: started very slowly, did not cover as much ground in each topic as we could have--maybe the details could have been decreased in order to cover more ground (i.e. we barely touched personality disorders) and i still would have been okay with it since it is a 100-level course

Professor Joormann did a great job of teaching us whats important to know about where the field is at but also where society is at in terms of mental illness. This could've been a cut and dry informative class but it went beyond that to critique and discuss. I particularly enjoyed the material for the reading responses because of how eye-opening it was and how it added to lecture.

Strengths: the content is genuinely interesting, and important to learn about (at least in my opinion). 
Weaknesses: The lectures are very disorganized. (Often what is being spoken on is not in line with the slide / you aren't sure what exactly you're supposed to know and to what depth / are told you'll learn more about something later etc). Additionally, each test is worth 40% of your grade which can be very stressful because they are mostly multiple choice.
The professor dwelled on a lot of basic subjects quite often.

The course materials and reading were interesting, but the lectures and TFs were overwhelmingly unhelpful. The lectures were super disorganized, and we were perpetually 15 minutes behind, so every class was finishing an old lecture and starting a new one even if we only had five minutes. The TFs split the lectures, so no one really knows what's going on. The grade in the class is basically your grade on the midterm and final (each is worth 40%), and you are never properly prepared to take the tests. I was really interested in the subject this course focused on, and I did manage to learn things from reading the textbook and readings outside of class, but I was disappointed by the class itself.

The strengths of the class is that everyone can relate to it on one aspect or another, at some point in the semester. Also, it includes videos that show what the disorders look like in real life. Something that could be improved is that the class is too boring. One can easily fall asleep through lecture and wake up and probably haven't missed anything.
Not have 2 tests be 40% of grade
The tests could be worth a little less. 80% is made up by two exams.

I think the format of the class is good and very engaging. The material was interesting and the exams were fair. I would say it could have been slightly more challenging, in that the exams tested at quite a surface level. Additionally, I would suggest that the lecture slides had everything that was needed to know, and this meant class attendance was quite low so I would suggest implementing different methods to encourage greater class attendance (like maybe 10% of grade coming from in-class participation quizzes).
I thought the course was great. Jutta Joormann is an amazing instructor.
Good pace and well spaced assignments.

Strengths: interesting subject material, fair grading system
Weaknesses: lectures have no logical flow (often jump between subjects and it's difficult to keep material straight), delivered in a quite boring way, way too much tiny material that you *may* need to try and memorize that doesn't feel very important
The weight of the exams (40% each) should be lowered and there should be more emphasis on papers/ a paper.
The class is interesting but the lectures are not very engaging
lectures a little dry at times
The strength of this course was the manageable workload and how accessible the content was. The weaknesses of this course was having the majority of the grades relying on only two exams.
It is hard to get engaged with such a huge class size, so maybe add a section once a week.

A strength was the Professor Joorman was an engaging lecturer and the TAs were very available for questions. A weakness was that it seemed unclear to me which textbook readings to do to support learning on what topics.
More examples of questions that may be presented on the exam for better preparation.

Strengths: good modern videos/interviews and interesting subject matter
weakness: some lectures had so much information that it was hard to digest/not as fun as when the class is broken up with videos/activities.

The course delivers formulaically on what it promises, but lectures are not especially rich, engaging, or surprising, and the course is not designed for intellectual challenge. In the future, I think it would be better if the lectures moved into the disorders more quickly (rather than spending so much time on introductory material that someone could get from an Intro Psych class), and if they offered fresh perspectives on mental health activism or how cutting-edge psychopathology interventions are developed.
I think a strength of this course is the variety of material that it covers but I think the course is a bit unclear about what is covered in examinations.

A strength of the course is its thorough discussion of various disorders. I thought a weakness was the timing; it seemed we spent an unusually long time on the background of abnormal psychology. I believe the history could've been covered in a single day and the fascinating articles Prof. Joormann had us read every week could be mentioned more in lecture.
Strengths: great lecturer and the text book used is great and very detailed. Discussion sections would help a lot more with engagement.
The material was interesting but lecture was slightly boring.

The course has very interesting content and Professor Joormann is very clearly knowledgable and passionate. I think it could be improved by switching up the lecture styles to keep them engaging since they were all conducted in the same manner. I also think it would be helpful to spend more time on etiology and other things that people who took intro psych knew but those who didn't did not.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not recommend this course because I did not feel involved throughout the semester.
Yes, this was a very interesting class and it really feels awesome to have learned all I did. The workload is not bad and exams are not too difficult either.
Good class to Credit/D, but if youre taking it for a grade, the midterms ask very specific questions from lectures that requires detailed studying. Also, the lectures are long and not very engaging.
Yes, I thought the course material was very interesting and gave me the tools to think critically about how mental health is talked about and treated.
Yes! But the tests are worth way too much- 40% of your grade for one test is crazy. Otherwise great 5th class
Definitely!!!!!
Great Credit/D
Yes, an interesting introduction to clinical psychology. Maybe not as interesting to those who have taken intro psych courses.
Yes, because the contents are interesting, but the class is not taking a lot of time and is not too challenging.
Depends on what a student is looking for. If they know this is material they want to learn about then yes, but if they are considering other psychology courses I think there could be others.
If there were a different instructor and curriculum, yes. The subject matter in itself is extremely interesting and important. The way the class was taught, though, was unhelpful and uninteresting.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to all students. Most people know someone who has a mental illness, and this course helps provide historical, psychological, and clinical context to this major public health issue. Course expectations are reasonable, and lectures are interesting. Particularly for people interested in medicine, this course is a must-take!

Sure! It's a pretty interesting class. I recommend it if you're looking for a good social science credit, fulfilling your psyc major requirements, or are just interested in learning about mental illness. I would, however, warn students interested in the class that there can be upsetting and/or graphic material sometimes, which is to be expected in a course about mental illness.

Take it for an SO credit or as an easy psych elective if you're a psych major. I think I went to class twice all year. Make a study guide based on the lecture slides (they get posted on Canvas), study that, and you'll do well on the exams.
Not a bad 5th credit. Interesting subject matter. Might fall asleep during class.
Yes
Yes if you are a psychology major and need to fill a core requirement-- this is interesting and also relatively easy.
Yes, especially if interested in psychology
I would if you are interested in a week by week look at disorders
It's interesting
It's a pretty good gut or fifth class. Material is inherently interesting, but not presented as so.
yes, good course and not too hard if you have a difficult workload otherwise
I think this knowledge is important for everyone to have.
Good 5th class.
Yes. fun

Perfect Credit/D
Perfect 5th class
It is a good gut but if you are a psych major or want to learn abnormal psych I would not waste your time.
Only if you're actually interested in learning about psychological disorders; otherwise, it can get very boring.
Yes. It is super interesting

I would recommend this to a student who is really interested in abnormal psychology or to a psych major - or to a student who wants a fairly interesting course that isn't too intellectually demanding.
It is a good class if you just want to learn about what constitutes disorders based on their actual diagnosable criteria. I found this kind of bland, but if you're into that, go for it!
Yes, it's a good fifth class -- fairly interesting material without too much work.
Yes, very informative class.
yes! interesting material applicable to everyone,  minimal courseload, a class to take for you even if you're not a psych major
Classic Yale gut
No, not really. The information should have been interesting but was presented so dryly that it was uninteresting, and thus hard to learn.
Sure
No.
Fantastic class. Jutta is incredible. Easy grading. Def study for the tests though.

I would recommend this course to another student as a nice, easy social science or 5th credit course. The professor often read off of the slides and sometimes was a little hard to follow. Additionally, the material taught on the various mental illnesses was very surface level. If one had taken AP Psychology in high school or Intro to Psychology here at Yale, this class would probably be very repetitive and boring. The exams were very straightforward (multiple choice and short answer questions) and non-cumulative which was very nice given the amount of illnesses and etiological paradigms that were covered. The TAs and professor are very responsive to questions and meeting to discuss topics outside of class. The lectures were often not very engaging. However, the Poll Everywhere questions, videos, and guest lecturers helped with this. As long as you went to class and took notes and studied a fair amount beforehand, you would do very well in the course. They also curved both exams which was nice. The final paper was also very straightforward and could be done on the movie of our choice. Overall, I liked that the course was easy and straightforward. The only thing was that it was often boring and not engaging at times. From what I have heard about Intro to Pysch and deciding between the two, my experience with the course has made me glad I took Abnormal Pysch.

Yes, a great introduction to the field of psychology and incredibly informative. I came in as a STEM student looking for my fifth class, hoping it would be laid-back and interesting, and that's exactly what it turned out to be. The reading responses are low stress, the paper is actually fun to write (as you can do it on a movie or paper), and the exams are straightforward if you have paid attention to the material. The professor herself stresses that you don't have to go to class if you don't want to, and instead you can read the textbook for a more in-depth look at the disorders. However, I found at times that material she stressed on in class was more likely to be on the exam. Sitting in class can be boring at times, as she reads off of the powerpoints for the most part, but the videos and reading responses make up for that as well. Overall, it's an interesting lecture that is great as an easy fifth credit.

I must confess: I did not much enjoy this course. As someone coming from a background in the hard sciences I was frustrated by the sometimes hand-wavy and constantly fluctuating diagnostic criteria of clinical psychology. Additionally, I wish more time was devoted to discussing which of the treatments we know work and which treatments are more hopeful Hail Marys. I am unsure, however, if my complaints stem more from nature of psychology or the specifics of this course, so it is difficult to tell if you would share my views. Regardless, the fairly light workload of this course and the *ridiculously easy* (multiple choice!!) exams could provide reason enough to take it.
